exercises.title: Verify SDN Tool Installation
exercises.description: Confirm that all required SDN tools are properly installed and functional
exercises.instructions:
1. Open a terminal
2. Run 'sudo mn --version' to check Mininet
3. Run 'ryu-manager --version' to check RYU
4. Run 'ovs-vsctl --version' to check Open vSwitch
5. Document the version numbers
exercises.expected_output: Mininet 2.3.0+\nRYU 4.34+\nOVS 2.13.0+
hints: If tools are missing, install via apt or pip

exercises.title: Single-VM Controller Connection
exercises.description: Set up and verify a working SDN environment with controller and switch on the same machine
exercises.instructions:
1. Terminal 1: Start RYU controller with 'ryu-manager ryu.app.simple_switch_13'
2. Terminal 2: Start Mininet with 'sudo mn --controller=remote,ip=127.0.0.1 --topo single,4'
3. In Mininet CLI, run 'ovs-vsctl show'
4. Verify controller connection shows 'is_connected: true'
5. Run 'pingall' to test connectivity
exercises.expected_output: Controller connected, 0% packet loss on pingall
hints: Use sudo mn -c to clean up previous sessions

exercises.title: Dual-VM Setup Configuration
exercises.description: Configure two virtual machines for external controller testing
exercises.instructions:
1. VM1 (Controller): Configure static IP (e.g., 192.168.1.50)
2. VM2 (Mininet): Configure static IP on same subnet (e.g., 192.168.1.51)
3. Test connectivity: ping from VM2 to VM1
4. Start RYU on VM1
5. Start Mininet on VM2 pointing to VM1: sudo mn --controller=remote,ip=192.168.1.50
6. Verify connection with ovs-vsctl show
exercises.expected_output: VMs ping successfully, controller connection established
hints: Ensure both VMs are on same subnet

exercises.title: Environment Troubleshooting
exercises.description: Practice diagnosing and fixing common SDN environment issues
exercises.instructions:
1. Intentionally start Mininet BEFORE controller
2. Observe the error or timeout
3. Use 'sudo mn -c' to clean up
4. Start controller first, then Mininet
5. Document the difference in behavior
exercises.expected_output: Understanding of startup order importance
hints: Controller must be running before Mininet starts

exercises.title: Flow Table Inspection After Setup
exercises.description: Examine the initial flow table state after environment setup
exercises.instructions:
1. Set up Single-VM environment
2. After pingall, run 'ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1'
3. Identify the default flow entries
4. Note the priority values
5. Count how many flows were installed
exercises.expected_output: Multiple flows with various priorities, CONTROLLER action visible
hints: Check for learned MAC address flows

exercises.title: Network Cleanup and Reset
exercises.description: Learn to properly clean up SDN environments
exercises.instructions:
1. After running Mininet, exit the CLI
2. Run 'sudo mn -c' to clean up
3. Verify cleanup with 'sudo ovs-vsctl show'
4. Check for leftover processes with 'ps aux | grep mininet'
5. Document the cleanup procedure
exercises.expected_output: Clean system with no residual Mininet processes or bridges

exercises.title: Port Configuration Verification
exercises.description: Verify OpenFlow port configuration between controller and switch
exercises.instructions:
1. Start RYU with default settings
2. Check which port RYU is listening on (usually 6653)
3. Start Mininet with matching port
4. If using non-standard port, specify it: --controller=remote,ip=127.0.0.1,port=6633
5. Verify connection
exercises.expected_output: Controller listening and switch connected on correct port

exercises.title: Exploring Mininet Topologies
exercises.description: Create and explore different pre-built Mininet topologies
exercises.instructions:
1. Start Mininet with 'sudo mn --topo minimal'
2. Run 'nodes' command and document the output
3. Run 'net' command to see network links
4. Exit and try 'sudo mn --topo linear,4'
5. Compare the topology structures
exercises.expected_output: Understanding of minimal vs linear topologies
hints: Linear,n = n switches in a line with n hosts

exercises.title: Host Command Execution
exercises.description: Practice executing commands on virtual hosts
exercises.instructions:
1. Start Mininet: sudo mn
2. Run 'h1 ifconfig' to see h1's network interface
3. Run 'h1 ip addr' for detailed address info
4. Run 'h1 route' to see routing table
5. Compare with h2's configuration
exercises.expected_output: Each host has unique IP in 10.0.0.0/8 subnet
hints: Each host is in its own network namespace

exercises.title: Connectivity Testing with pingall
exercises.description: Use pingall to test network-wide connectivity
exercises.instructions:
1. Start Mininet: sudo mn --topo single,5
2. Run 'pingall' immediately and note results
3. Run 'pingall' again and observe differences
4. Explain why the second pingall might be different
exercises.expected_output: First pingall may have drops, second should be 0% loss
hints: Reactive flow installation causes first-packet delay
ARP learning occurs during first pingall

exercises.title: Link Manipulation
exercises.description: Dynamically change network topology by manipulating links
exercises.instructions:
1. sudo mn --topo linear,3
2. Run pingall (should succeed)
3. Run 'link s1 s2 down'
4. Run pingall again and observe results
5. Run 'link s1 s2 up' and test again
exercises.expected_output: Connectivity breaks when link is down, restores when up
hints: Observe which hosts can still communicate

exercises.title: iperf Performance Testing
exercises.description: Measure network throughput using iperf
exercises.instructions:
1. Start Mininet: sudo mn
2. Run 'iperf h1 h2' to test TCP throughput
3. Note the bandwidth result
4. Run multiple times and check consistency
5. Document baseline performance
exercises.expected_output: Throughput in Gbps range for virtual environment
hints: Virtual links typically show very high throughput

exercises.title: Custom Mininet Commands
exercises.description: Create a custom command sequence for network testing
exercises.instructions:
1. Start Mininet
2. Create a test sequence: nodes → net → dump → pingall → iperf h1 h2
3. Document each output
4. Explain what information each command provides
5. Save as a testing checklist
exercises.expected_output: Complete network characterization checklist

exercises.title: Mininet Cleanup Best Practices
exercises.description: Learn proper Mininet cleanup procedures
exercises.instructions:
1. Start and exit Mininet multiple times
2. Check for leftover bridges: sudo ovs-vsctl show
3. Practice cleanup: sudo mn -c
4. Verify all switches are removed
5. Check for zombie processes: ps aux | grep mininet
exercises.expected_output: Clean system ready for next session
hints: Verify no bridges or processes remain

exercises.title: RYU Controller Startup
exercises.description: Launch RYU controller with different applications
exercises.instructions:
1. Try: ryu-manager ryu.app.simple_switch_13
2. Observe startup messages
3. Note the listening port
4. Try alternative app: ryu-manager ryu.app.gui_topology.gui_topology
5. Document differences
exercises.expected_output: Controller starts successfully, shows application loaded

exercises.title: Controller-Switch Handshake
exercises.description: Observe and verify the OpenFlow handshake process
exercises.instructions:
1. Start RYU controller
2. Watch controller terminal output
3. In another terminal, start Mininet
4. Observe handshake messages (HELLO, FEATURES_REQUEST, etc.)
5. Verify switch connects successfully
exercises.expected_output: Successful OpenFlow handshake visible in logs

exercises.title: Verify Controller Connection
exercises.description: Confirm controller-switch connection using OVS commands
exercises.instructions:
1. Setup: RYU + Mininet on localhost
2. In Mininet CLI: ovs-vsctl show
3. Find the Controller section
4. Verify 'is_connected: true'
5. Note the controller IP and port
exercises.expected_output: Controller tcp:127.0.0.1:6653 is_connected: true
hints: Look for Controller section in ovs-vsctl output

exercises.title: Reactive Flow Installation Observation
exercises.description: Watch the RYU controller install flows reactively
exercises.instructions:
1. Start RYU with simple_switch_13
2. Start Mininet
3. Run 'ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1' (should be empty or minimal)
4. Run 'h1 ping -c 1 h2'
5. Run dump-flows again and observe new flows
6. Document what flows were added
exercises.expected_output: New MAC learning flows appear after ping

exercises.title: Packet-In Event Monitoring
exercises.description: Monitor packet-in events in the RYU controller logs
exercises.instructions:
1. Start RYU controller (watch terminal output)
2. Start Mininet
3. Generate traffic: pingall
4. Observe 'EventOFPPacketIn' messages in RYU terminal
5. Count how many packet-in events occur
6. Explain why these events happen
exercises.expected_output: Multiple EventOFPPacketIn messages during first pingall
hints: Packet-in = unknown packet sent to controller

exercises.title: Multiple Switch Management
exercises.description: Connect multiple switches to a single RYU controller
exercises.instructions:
1. Start RYU controller
2. Start Mininet with linear topology: sudo mn --topo linear,3 --controller remote
3. Run 'ovs-vsctl show' to see all switches
4. Verify all switches connect to same controller
5. Test inter-switch communication with pingall
exercises.expected_output: All 3 switches connected to single controller, full connectivity
hints: Each switch will have separate connection

exercises.title: Controller Log Analysis
exercises.description: Analyze RYU controller logs for debugging
exercises.instructions:
1. Start RYU with verbose logging
2. Start Mininet and generate traffic
3. Review controller logs for:
   - Connection events
   - Packet-in events
   - Flow-mod installations
4. Document the event sequence
5. Identify any errors or warnings
exercises.expected_output: Complete event timeline from connection to flow installation

title: Manual Flow Installation - Drop All
description: Create a flow rule that drops all traffic
instructions:
1. Start Mininet: sudo mn --controller=none
2. Add drop rule: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'actions=drop'
3. Test: pingall (should fail completely)
4. View flows: sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1
5. Delete flows: sudo ovs-ofctl del-flows s1
expected_output: 100% packet loss, flow visible with actions=drop

title: Priority-Based Flow Matching
description: Understand how priority affects flow selection
instructions:
1. Start Mininet without controller
2. Add low priority: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'priority=100,actions=normal'
3. Add high priority drop: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'priority=200,actions=drop'
4. Test pingall
5. Delete high priority flow and test again
expected_output: Higher priority rules are matched first

title: Port-Based Forwarding
description: Create static forwarding rules based on port numbers
instructions:
1. sudo mn --topo single,3 --controller=none
2. Check port assignments: sudo ovs-ofctl show s1
3. Add rule: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'in_port=1,actions=output:2'
4. Add reverse: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'in_port=2,actions=output:1'
5. Test: h1 ping -c 2 h2
6. Try h1 ping h3 (should fail - no rule)
hints: Check port numbers with ovs-ofctl show

title: L2 MAC Address Matching
description: Implement static L2 switching with MAC addresses
instructions:
1. sudo mn --controller=none
2. Get MAC addresses: h1 ifconfig, h2 ifconfig
3. Add ARP flood rule: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'dl_type=0x0806,actions=flood'
4. Add MAC forwarding rules for each host
5. Test with pingall
expected_output: Ping works with static MAC-based forwarding
hints: dl_src = source MAC, dl_dst = destination MAC

title: L3 IP-Based Routing
description: Create IP-based forwarding rules
instructions:
1. sudo mn --controller=none
2. Add ARP rule: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'dl_type=0x0806,actions=flood'
3. Add IP rules: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'ip,nw_dst=10.0.0.1,actions=output:1'
4. Add rule for 10.0.0.2
5. Test with ping

title: L4 Port Filtering
description: Block specific TCP/UDP ports
instructions:
1. sudo mn --controller=none
2. Add base rule: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'priority=100,actions=normal'
3. Block HTTP: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'priority=200,tcp,tp_dst=80,actions=drop'
4. Test ICMP (should work)
5. Test HTTP with 'h1 python -m SimpleHTTPServer' then 'h2 wget h1:8000'

title: Flow Statistics Monitoring
description: Monitor flow usage through packet/byte counters
instructions:
1. Set up flows from previous exercises
2. Run: sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1
3. Note n_packets and n_bytes
4. Generate traffic with iperf
5. Dump flows again and calculate throughput

title: Analyzing Controller-Installed Flows
description: Examine flows installed by the RYU controller
instructions:
1. Start RYU with simple_switch_13
2. Start Mininet
3. Run pingall to trigger flow installation
4. Examine: sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1
5. Identify: priority values, match fields, actions, idle/hard timeouts

title: Reactive Mode Analysis
description: Observe reactive flow installation behavior
instructions:
1. Start RYU controller
2. Start Mininet
3. Before traffic: sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1 (minimal flows)
4. Send one ping: h1 ping -c 1 h2
5. Dump flows again (new flows appeared)
6. Note which flows were added

title: Proactive Flow Installation
description: Pre-install flows before traffic
instructions:
1. sudo mn --controller=none
2. Pre-install all necessary flows
3. Test pingall (should work immediately)
4. Compare first-packet latency with reactive mode
hints: All pings should have similar latency

title: CONTROLLER Action Testing
description: Observe packet-in behavior with CONTROLLER action
instructions:
1. Start RYU
2. Start Mininet
3. Add rule: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'priority=100,icmp,actions=CONTROLLER'
4. Ping and watch RYU terminal for EventOFPPacketIn
5. Count packet-in events
expected_output: Each ICMP packet triggers packet-in event

title: Flow Timeout Configuration
description: Experiment with idle and hard timeouts
instructions:
1. sudo mn --controller=none
2. Add flow with timeout: sudo ovs-ofctl add-flow s1 'idle_timeout=10,priority=100,actions=normal'
3. Generate traffic
4. Wait 10 seconds without traffic
5. Dump flows - rule should be gone

title: Table-Miss Entry Analysis
description: Understand the default/miss entry behavior
instructions:
1. Start RYU + Mininet
2. Dump flows: look for priority=0 entry
3. This is the table-miss entry
4. Note its action (usually CONTROLLER)
5. Explain when this entry is used
hints: Matches when no other rules match

title: Comparing Reactive vs Proactive Performance
description: Measure latency differences between modes
instructions:
1. Reactive: Start RYU, do h1 ping -c 10 h2, note first vs subsequent latency
2. Proactive: Pre-install flows, ping again
3. Document latency differences
4. Calculate first-packet penalty
expected_output: Proactive has consistent low latency, reactive has first-packet delay
hints: First packet in reactive mode goes to controller

title: Wireshark OpenFlow Capture
description: Capture and analyze OpenFlow handshake with Wireshark
instructions:
1. Start Wireshark: sudo wireshark
2. Select 'Loopback: lo' interface
3. Apply filter: openflow_v4
4. Start RYU controller
5. Start Mininet
6. Capture HELLO, FEATURES_REQUEST, FEATURES_REPLY messages
7. Take screenshots

title: Packet-In Message Analysis
description: Capture and analyze PACKET_IN messages
instructions:
1. Wireshark running with openflow_v4 filter
2. Start RYU + Mininet
3. Send ping: h1 ping -c 1 h2
4. Find PACKET_IN messages in Wireshark
5. Examine payload (should contain original ping)
hints: Look for ICMP inside OpenFlow message

title: Flow-Mod Message Inspection
description: Observe FLOW_MOD messages installing flows
instructions:
1. Wireshark with openflow_v4 filter
2. RYU + Mininet running
3. Generate traffic
4. Find FLOW_MOD messages
5. Examine match fields and actions

title: Flow Statistics Collection
description: Request and analyze flow statistics
instructions:
1. Setup RYU + Mininet
2. Generate traffic
3. Request stats: sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows s1
4. Note: n_packets, n_bytes, duration
5. Generate more traffic and compare

title: Port Statistics Monitoring
description: Monitor per-port traffic statistics
instructions:
1. RYU + Mininet setup
2. Baseline: sudo ovs-ofctl dump-ports s1
3. Run iperf h1 h2
4. Dump ports again
5. Calculate throughput from rx/tx byte counters

title: RYU GUI Topology Visualization
description: Use RYU's built-in GUI for topology visualization
instructions:
1. Start RYU with GUI: ryu-manager --observe-links ryu.app.gui_topology.gui_topology ryu.app.simple_switch_13
2. Open browser: http://localhost:8080
3. Start Mininet with tree topology
4. Observe automatic topology discovery
5. Generate traffic and watch flow updates
expected_output: Visual topology map with switches and links

title: LLDP Discovery Analysis
description: Analyze LLDP protocol for topology discovery
instructions:
1. Start Wireshark
2. RYU with GUI app
3. Start Mininet
4. Capture LLDP packets (filter: lldp)
5. Examine LLDP contents (chassis ID, port ID)
6. Understand how controller builds topology map
hints: Controller uses it to map topology

title: MiniEdit GUI Topology Design
description: Create a custom topology using MiniEdit graphical interface
instructions:
1. Launch: sudo ~/mininet/examples/miniedit.py
2. Add 3 switches in a triangle
3. Add 2 hosts per switch
4. Connect all switches together
5. Add a remote controller
6. Run the topology and test with pingall

title: Export MiniEdit Topology Script
description: Save MiniEdit topology as Python script
instructions:
1. Create topology in MiniEdit
2. File → Export Level 2 Script
3. Save as myTopo.py
4. Exit MiniEdit
5. Run: sudo python myTopo.py
6. Verify topology loads correctly

title: Custom Python Topology Class
description: Write a custom topology using Mininet Python API
instructions:
1. Create file: nano myCustomTopo.py
2. Import: from mininet.topo import Topo
3. Create class MyTopo(Topo)
4. Add switches and hosts in build() method
5. Run: sudo mn --custom myCustomTopo.py --topo mytopo

title: Linear Topology Script
description: Create a linear topology with variable switch count
instructions:
1. Write Python class for linear topology
2. Accept parameter for number of switches
3. Create switches s1, s2, ... sN
4. Add one host per switch
5. Link switches in a line
6. Test with different N values
hints: Use loop to create N switches

title: Tree Topology Implementation
description: Build a tree topology with depth and fanout parameters
instructions:
1. Create tree topology class
2. Parameters: depth, fanout
3. Implement recursive tree building
4. Test with depth=2, fanout=2
5. Verify connectivity with pingall

title: Link Parameter Configuration
description: Configure link bandwidth and delay
instructions:
1. Create custom topology
2. Add link with parameters: self.addLink(h1, s1, bw=10, delay='5ms')
3. Test throughput with iperf
4. Verify ~10 Mbps bandwidth
5. Check ping latency (~5ms round-trip)
expected_output: Links have configured bandwidth and delay

title: Multi-Controller Topology
description: Create topology with multiple controllers
instructions:
1. Start two RYU controllers on different ports
2. Create topology with 2 switches
3. Assign each switch to different controller
4. Test inter-switch communication
expected_output: Each switch connected to separate controller

title: Hub Application Implementation
description: Create a simple hub that floods all packets
instructions:
1. Create hub_app.py
2. Import RYU libraries
3. Implement packet_in_handler
4. Action: FLOOD all packets
5. Test: ryu-manager hub_app.py, then sudo mn --controller remote
6. Verify all hosts receive broadcast traffic
expected_output: All packets flooded to all ports

title: L2 Learning Switch
description: Implement MAC address learning switch
instructions:
1. Create l2_switch.py
2. Maintain mac_to_port dictionary
3. Learn source MAC on packet_in
4. Install flow if destination MAC is known
5. Flood if destination unknown
6. Test and verify learning behavior
expected_output: Switch learns MACs and stops flooding

title: L3 Simple Router
description: Implement basic IP routing
instructions:
1. Create router_app.py
2. Handle ARP separately (flood)
3. Match on IP destination
4. Forward based on routing table
5. Test cross-subnet routing

title: L4 Service Firewall
description: Block specific TCP/UDP services
instructions:
1. Create firewall_app.py
2. Define blocked ports (e.g., 80 for HTTP)
3. Check tp_dst in packet_in
4. Drop if port is blocked
5. Allow other traffic
6. Test: ICMP works, HTTP blocked

title: VLAN-like Network Isolation
description: Implement network segmentation
instructions:
1. Create isolation_app.py
2. Define groups: h1,h2 in group A; h3,h4 in group B
3. Allow intra-group traffic
4. Block inter-group traffic
5. Test: h1 can ping h2, but not h3

title: Proactive Firewall Rules
description: Pre-install firewall rules proactively
instructions:
1. Create proactive_firewall.py
2. Install all firewall rules at startup
3. Don't use packet_in for firewall decisions
4. Test immediate enforcement
5. Compare with reactive approach
hints: No controller involvement for blocked traffic

title: Controller Application Debugging
description: Debug RYU applications effectively
instructions:
1. Add logging to your app
2. Use self.logger.info(), .debug(), .error()
3. Run with --verbose flag
4. Intentionally create a bug
5. Use logs to identify and fix it

title: Round-Robin Load Balancer
description: Distribute traffic across multiple backend servers
instructions:
1. Create loadbalancer_app.py
2. Define backend server pool
3. Implement round-robin selection
4. Rewrite destination IP/MAC to selected backend
5. Install bidirectional flows
6. Test with multiple clients

title: Multi-Field Advanced Firewall
description: Implement complex firewall with multiple criteria
instructions:
1. Create advanced_firewall.py
2. Rule 1: Block external subnet to DB port 3306
3. Rule 2: Allow HTTP/HTTPS from specific sources
4. Rule 3: Rate-limit SSH connections
5. Test each rule individually
6. Document rule priority and conflicts

title: Network Telemetry Collection
description: Build monitoring system with statistics collection
instructions:
1. Create monitor_app.py
2. Periodically request flow stats
3. Periodically request port stats
4. Store in data structure or export to file
5. Generate reports: top talkers, throughput per flow
hints: Use set_ev_cls for stats reply events

title: Simple Intrusion Detection System
description: Detect suspicious traffic patterns
instructions:
1. Create ids_app.py
2. Detect: Multiple connection attempts to different ports (port scan)
3. Detect: High packet rate from single source
4. Alert when threshold exceeded
5. Optionally install blocking flow
6. Test with nmap or hping3

title: DDoS Mitigation System
description: Rate-limit or block flooding sources
instructions:
1. Create ddos_mitigation.py
2. Track packet rate per source IP
3. If rate > threshold, install drop flow
4. Simulate attack: h1 hping3 --flood h2
5. Verify attacker blocked, victim protected
6. Measure victim throughput before/during/after

title: Stateful Firewall Implementation
description: Track connection state for bidirectional traffic
instructions:
1. Create stateful_firewall.py
2. Track established TCP connections
3. Allow return traffic for established connections
4. Block unsolicited inbound connections
5. Test client-initiated connections (allowed)
6. Test server-initiated connections (blocked)

title: Security Project Documentation
description: Create comprehensive project report
instructions:
1. Choose a security application (firewall, IDS, or load balancer)
2. Document: Architecture, algorithm, code structure
3. Create test plan and execute tests
4. Measure performance metrics
5. Analyze false positives/negatives
6. Write complete report with diagrams
